text: glitz and glamour are usually the order
of the day at the new york auto show but
this year times are tough the economy is
bad and auto sales are in the tank and
US automakers like General Motors and
especially a dodge and chrysler
minimalism is the new order of the day
this Dodge Challenger looked great but
it's not a new model there aren't very
many new models in the pipeline anymore
a dodging Chrysler because so many
things that had to be cancelled due to
financial difficulties what they are
reminding people of here though is like
this board behind me says value you can
get some pretty cheap deals right now
they're also reminding people of their
heritage they'd like to tell people
we've been around for a lot of years and
we hope we're around for a lot more
years to come
I wouldn't say the mood is funeral here
at General Motors but everybody
scattered pretty quickly after this new
GMC Terrain crossover was introduced
here this morning and that was GM's big
announcement at the New York show this
year there weren't any high-level
executives here to introduce the vehicle
either and the ones who were on site
didn't want to talk to us on the record
on camera most likely the brain trust of
the company is back in Detroit working
feverishly on a new reorganization plan
which they hope will rescue the company
from all most eminent bankruptcy that
could be as little as a couple of weeks
away by comparison over here at Ford
things are a lot more lively this could
be the last man standing in American
auto industry the way things are going
Ford is not having the kinds of
financial troubles the GM and Chrysler
are they've not needed government
handouts they've got their debt pretty
much under control and they've got some
new models coming out and there seems to
be a lot of excitement here and a lot of
enthusiasm at the company we're very
excited because we have such a huge
product rollout this year we have the
new tourists coming we introduce the new
f-150 this year this is all a result of
the plan that we started more than three
years ago to really restructure our

be paying office
and of course it's some automakers that
despite the business slow down they're

for the new york times i'm gerry Garrett
